University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. Never too late to learn: what motivates mature students to return to learning? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/january/never-too-late-to-learn-what-motivates-mature-students-to-return-to-learning New project from our Vaughan Centre for Lifelong Learning and School of Psychology

A new project has been awarded funding from the College of Social Science Research Development Fund to investigate the motivations and outcomes for mature students who study at undergraduate level part-time.

The study involves Dr Nalita James, Olivia Harrison, and Farhat Syyeda from the Vaughan Centre for Lifelong Learning and Dr Diana Pinto from the Centre and our School of Psychology.

The research comes at a time when there are declining numbers and completion rates amongst part-time student numbers in higher education. In England, part-time entrants fell by 42 per cent between 2008 and 2012 (HEFCE, 2014). Given that England\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds growing and ageing population has increased the stock of potential part-time students in recent years, demographic pressures seem unlikely to be a driver of the decline in part-time entrants. Rather, evidence suggests that the sharp decline in part-time entrants may be due to a combination of higher education policy and funding changes and challenging macroeconomic conditions, which have persisted beyond the end of the official recession. Part-time mature students may experience \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhigher education\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in very different ways, which in turn can impact in particular ways on their identity and vital sense of belonging. In widening the focus of traditional conceptions of HE, the research will examine how to better support mature part-time learners and in doing so enhance student experience and increase retention rates.

The project will be completed in June 2015 and a research seminar will be held at the Vaughan Centre for Lifelong Learning to disseminate the findings.

]]> No publisher pt91 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Psychology Lifelong learning Magazine:Student 2015-01-14T13:11:11Z Blog Entry Traumatised children worldwide to be helped by major project https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/january/traumatised-children-worldwide-to-be-helped-by-major-project Professor Panos Vostanis to aid affected communities in low income countries Professor Panos Vostanis from the Greenwood Institute of Child Health based at the University's School of Psychology\ufffd\ufffdwill be\ufffd\ufffdembarking on a global mission to help child victims of trauma in low income countries around the world.

Starting in Mumbai, where Professor Vostanis will be visiting between 22-28 January, he will be training practitioners and volunteer workers of two large charities \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the Dr Leo Barnes Foundation and the Ramakrishna Mission - and will be visiting communities affected by trauma.

Some of these visits will include shelter houses for children up to the age of 18, slum areas where children affected by drug abuse live, villages exposed to tuberculosis and leprosy and orphanages for children who have been abandoned or have lost their parents.

His travels will then take him to Kocaeli in Turkey, with Professor Nisha Dogra from the University of Leicester School of Psychology, followed by Nakuru, Kenya, to provide training and psychosocial support to victims of ethnic conflict.

Regular updates on the progress of the training and Professor Vostanis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds experiences during the project will be regularly communicated through twitter at: @pv11Panos

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Psychology Magazine:Research Magazine:Student 2015-01-13T11:25:00Z Blog Entry Funding boost for post-graduate training across the UK to reduce and improve animal research https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/december/funding-boost-for-post-graduate-training-across-the-uk-to-reduce-and-improve-animal-research Research into Stroke using rodents benefits from funding The\ufffd\ufffdNational Centre for the Replacement, Refinement & Reduction of Animals (NC3Rs) has invested \ufffd\ufffd900,000 to support studentship projects at eight UK institutions, including the University of Leicester.

Each of the projects will investigate ways to either replace the use of animals in research, reduce the number of animals used or improve laboratory animal welfare.

The ten PhD studentships will each receive \ufffd\ufffd90,000 over a three-year period. The projects range from developing a model of ovarian cancer in a small silicone device, to seeking insights into the underlying biology of aging using roundworms.

Two of the projects funded will focus on improving welfare and minimising the suffering of rodents used in stroke research.

Dr Claire Gibson (picture), Head of\ufffd\ufffdthe School of Psychology,\ufffd\ufffdwill supervise a project aimed at improving well-being by providing enrichment, improving understanding of the humane use of non-invasive monitoring and assessing whether a surgical intervention can reduce mortality and morbidity in experimental stroke rodents.

She said:\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLike other leading universities, Leicester is committed to applying the principles of the 3Rs to animal research and exploring both alternatives and refinements to the use of animals for the purposes of biomedical research. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Psychology Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff 2014-12-10T12:28:21Z Blog Entry University of Leicester part of scheme to enhance cultural training for medical students https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/november/university-of-leicester-part-of-scheme-to-introduce-cultural-training-for-medical-students Members of a Europe-wide initiative aiming to improve the cultural competence of medical students are to converge on the University campus in December Medical students at the University are to receive training in how to become \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdculturally competent\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd as part of the medical curriculum as a consequence of widespread migration across Europe.

Members of a Europe-wide initiative, Culturally Competent in Medical Education (C2ME), to equip medical students and their educators with cultural skills \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd alongside lifesaving ones \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd will converge at the University from 1-2 December.

C2ME is a consortium involving 14 partners across 11 countries \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and Leicester is the only university in England that is in the consortium.

Consortium member Professor Nisha Dogra (pictured) from the School of Psychology said the key aim of the project is to ensure that staff teaching medical students - both doctors and other staff - are aware of their own identities and views on the subject as this can influence what and how they teach medical students about diversity.

In 1997 Professor Dogra developed an innovative programme to teach medical students about cultural diversity and since then she has been involved in educational developments in this field both national and internationally. Professor Dogra was one of the founders of the Diversity in Medicine and Health (DIMAH) group and is the current chair.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Medicine Magazine:Student Psychology Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff 2014-11-28T10:40:00Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million project provides platform for PhD students to pursue innovative research https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/november/20ac2-9-million-project-provides-platform-for-phd-students-to-pursue-innovative-research Launch of INTREPID Forensics at annual Forensic Sciences Conference The Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences held its annual conference at College Court, the University's conference centre and hotel, on 7-8 November and during the event officially launched the Interdisciplinary Training and Research Programme for Innovative Doctorates in Forensic Science (INTREPID Forensics).

INTREPID Forensics is a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million multidisciplinary project funded by the People Programme of the European Union\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Seventh Framework Programme and provides funding for 10 early stage researchers to pursue innovative research degrees focussing on areas applicable to the forensic sciences.

The project received nearly 300 applications from 58 different countries. The researchers will investigate forensic technologies with the potential to impact crime across Europe and globally.

The research projects are all based at the University of Leicester and are co-supervised by academics in a wide range of disciplines including Genetics, Criminology, Chemistry, Psychology, Engineering, Mathematics, Physics, Pathology and Immunity, Infection and Inflammation.

Dr Lisa Smith, INTREPID Forensics Project Coordinator and senior lecturer in the Department of Criminology, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences conference and postgraduate symposium was the perfect event for the launch of the INTREPID Forensics project. It provided a great opportunity for the ten PhD researchers on the INTREPID project to network with other postgraduate students and industry experts, as well as raising awareness of the project within the wider forensic community.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Anya Hunt, CEO of the Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences, added: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences were delighted to host their annual Autumn conference and AGM at College Court in Leicester this year. In the 30th anniversary year since the DNA profiling discovery at the University of Leicester, and with the launch if the INTREPID Forensics project, it was an opportunity not to be missed. The Society\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds trace evidence conference and parallel post graduate research symposium, organised in conjunction with Dr. Lisa Smith, were both a huge success. We look forward to seeing the INTREPID project develop and we hope to see the student present their findings at future events.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The conference, held at College Court, focused on the theme of trace evidence and attracted academics and practitioners from across the forensic sciences. There was also a Postgraduate Symposium which featured student research presentations from universities all over the UK and across a wide range of forensic disciplines.\ufffd\ufffd

All of the INTREPID Forensics researchers are writing research blogs about their experiences over the next three years. People can subscribe to the blogs by visiting the project website.

]]> No publisher ap507 Chemistry Psychology Genetics pathology Engineering Criminology Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Physics Mathematics 2014-11-18T11:40:00Z Blog Entry New test helps victims of brain injury recover https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/october/new-test-helps-victims-of-brain-injury-recover Dr Gerald Burgess develops assessment to help sufferers of damage to the brain Dr Gerald Burgess from the School of Psychology has developed\ufffd\ufffda dynamic new assessment for helping victims of trauma to the brain, including those suffering from progressive conditions such as dementia.

The Short Parallel Assessments of Neuropsychological Status (SPANS) has been designed to engage with patients suffering from a variety of brain injuries in order to aid in their recovery\ufffd\ufffdand\ufffd\ufffdmeasures the cognitive skills of individuals\ufffd\ufffdin a user-friendly and concise way, taking patients an estimated 35 minutes to complete.

Dr Burgess said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWith SPANS clinicians now have a broader and more reliable assessment that is even more useful than most tests for tracking changes in cognitive skills over time. Patients are now more thoroughly assessed by\ufffd\ufffda test\ufffd\ufffdthat is less taxing on them than some other tests, so that their difficulties may be better understood.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The test is suitable to be administered by a range of healthcare professionals, including clinical or research psychologists, occupational therapists, speech and language therapists, psychiatrists and neurologists.

During the development of SPANS Dr Burgess worked with Hogrefe, the publisher, who helped in collecting data and developing SPANS to a professional standard through production and marketing efforts.

For more information about SPANS visit Hogrefe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds website.

A paper about the development and use of SPANS is available here.

  • Press Release

Watch a video showing Dr Gerald Burgess discussing SPANS in detail below:

]]> No publisher ap507 Psychology Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff 2014-10-20T10:10:54Z Blog Entry Undergraduate student publishes debut novel https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/october/undergraduate-student-publishes-debut-novel Psychology student Hawa Mansaray publishes 'The Tale of Frankie Fox and Terry Toad' First year undergraduate student\ufffd\ufffdHawa Mansaray, 19,\ufffd\ufffdwho is studying Psychology at the University,\ufffd\ufffdhas become a published author after\ufffd\ufffdwriting a children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds book called the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Tale of Frankie Fox and Terry Toad\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, which is available to purchase worldwide in hard copy and eBook format through several major retailers including Amazon and WHSmith.

The book was officially launched in June 2014 at the Bacon College in London with 150 guests attending, and it will also be exhibited at two major events in Spain and Germany this autumn.

Hawa said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMy main incentive and motivation is my family \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd my younger siblings in particular. It was important to me to be able to do something they can look at and be proud of. I believe this book is unique because it is a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdchoose your own destiny\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd story for a very young age demographic of 4-10years.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Alongside studying, Hawa operates as a social entrepreneur and her endeavours have been supported through the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Career Development Service where she has been able to gain access to business training and funding.

She added: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThrough my involvement with the Enterprise Team in the Career Development Service here at Leicester, I was introduced to UnLtd who provide funding to support social impact projects and I was fortunate enough to secure \ufffd\ufffd2,000 towards costs\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

Susan Root, Enterprise Project Officer at the University, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe would like to congratulate Hawa on the launch of her book, she has made a great start to university life, exploiting opportunities and developing strong business acumen in the process. She is a first year, first class student who possesses the key skills and attributes required to become a successful entrepreneur."

A percentage of the book\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds profits will be going to support The National Literacy Trust (NLT) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a national charity dedicated to raising literacy levels in the UK.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Tale of Frankie Fox and Terry Toad\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdis available to order through\ufffd\ufffdthe University's bookshop.

]]> No publisher ap507 Psychology Magazine:Student 2014-10-17T12:10:00Z Blog Entry Effectiveness of eyewitness identification procedures https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/october/effectiveness-of-eyewitness-identification-procedures Research involving Leicester informs US report Psychologist Dr Heather Flowe (pictured) and her collaborators have been involved in a new \ufffd\ufffdstudy into the effectiveness of eyewitness identification procedures.

Their work could change the way US law enforcement gathers evidence.

The National Academy of Sciences (NAS), a non-profit scientific advisory organization, based in Washington, USA, has released a report on strengthening the value of eyewitness evidence.

The report was based on scientific evidence gathered by numerous sources including a paper co-authored by Dr Heather Flowe, from the University of Leicester's School of Psychology.

The study, Receiver Operating Characteristics Analysis of Eyewitness Memory: Comparing the Diagnostic Accuracy of Simultaneous Versus Sequential Lineups, was used for its recommendations concerning lineup presentation procedures.

And it played a pivotal role in the NAS report, titled, Identifying the Culprit, which focuses on methods to improve the way in which police officers collect reports from witnesses, strengthen the value of eyewitness reports in court, and improve the scientific foundation underpinning eyewitness identification.

Dr Flowe, from our School of Psychology, \ufffd\ufffdworked with Dr. Laura Mickes (Royal Holloway University of London) and Professor John Wixted (University of California, San Diego), to determine whether police lineups were more successful at obtaining accurate results if the lineup members were viewed simultaneously (as a group) or sequentially (one-by-one).

  • Press release

Listen to the NAS podcast here

]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Psychology Magazine:Staff 2014-10-10T14:16:57Z Blog Entry Thought Leadership \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Latest Ofsted report is unfair, tiny magnetic pulses improve memory and apprenticeships are more effective in small firms. https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/october/thought-leadership-2013-latest-ofsted-report-is-unfair-tiny-magnetic-pulses-improves-memory-and-apprenticeships-are-more-effective-in-small-firms Read latest views, blogs and opinions from Leicester academics and join The Conversation. In the latest of a series of opinion pieces, Dr Christopher Wilkins (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdfrom the School of Education,discusses on The Conversation issues relating to how to manage children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds behaviour in the classroom.

An additional article by Dr Elizabeth Maratos from the School of Psychology,explains on The Conversation how zapping the brain with tiny magnetic pulses improves memory.

And in the latest Management is too Important Not to Debate Blog,Dr Daniel Bishop from the School of Management, is reporting provisional findings from his ongoing study of apprenticeships. In the post he challenges the politically predominant notion that large firms do it best.

You can discover other thought-provoking pieces on The Conversation ,Leicester Exchanges and Management is too Important Not to Debate Blog.

Leicester academics\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd contributions to The Conversation have attracted praise. Andrew Naughtie, Politics and Society Deputy Editor from The Conversation said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdUniversity of Leicester are a tremendous asset as a member. I've had a lot of authors from there write pieces of high quality, and the impact of the university becoming a member has been really noticeable \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd having quick responses from our morning email and the press office has definitely helped us generate more high-quality writing that's as close to the news cycle as possible.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Join the Conversation

The University has joined other leading universities across the UK that have already partnered with The Conversation to post thought-provoking comment pieces.

The Conversation is an independent source of news and views, sourced from the academic and research community and delivered direct to the public. The site launched in Australia in March 2011. Since then it has grown to become one of Australia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds largest independent news and commentary sites.

The Conversation has a monthly audience of 2 million users, and reach of 10 million through Creative Commons republication. It has a growing community of more than 14,400 academics and researchers from 912 institutions. Writing content for The Conversation enables you to sign off on your articles, so you retain full control over what is being published. You can become an author and pitch an idea as well.

Many academics from the University have already contributed to The Conversation and enjoyed working with the editors. Their articles can be found here.

Professor Martin Parker from the School of Management said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWorking with The Conversation is easy. You write something interesting and they help you make it into a sharp and engaging article. You are being edited by real journalists, and it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a great way of getting your ideas to a broader audience.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Andrew Futter from the Politics and International Relations said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWorking with the editors at the conversation is a pleasure; they are very professional, turn articles around very quickly and are highly competent.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

For further information about writing for The Conversation, contact the Press Office on pressoffice@le.ac.uk / sb661@le.ac.uk\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd / +44(0)116 252 5761.

\ufffd\ufffd

\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher sb661 Psychology Management Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Politics Education 2014-10-09T09:45:00Z Blog Entry Herbert Gintis Lecture: Five Principles for the Unification of the Behavioural Sciences https://www2.le.ac.uk/colleges/socsci/college%20news/herbert-gintis-lecture World-renowned social scientist and leading economist, Professor Herbert Gintis, will deliver a public lecture on 15 October 2014 at 5pm in Rattray Lower Ground Floor Lecture Theatre, followed by a reception in Charles Wilson. Professor Herbert Gintis will outline how behavioural sciences can be united by core principles and a common understanding of human behaviour.

With an MA in Mathematics and PhD in Economics from Harvard University, Professor Herbert Gintis holds an array of prestigious positions:

  • Professor of Economics at Central European University
  • Visiting Professor at University of Siena
  • External Professor at Santa Fe Institute
  • Emeritus Professor of Economics at University of Massachusetts.

A leading contributor to all of the social sciences, Gintis strongly believes that cross discipline research is key for the advancement of social science:

Event details:
Date 15 October 2014
Time 5pm
Venue The Rattray, University of Leicester
Cost Free to attend
Book now
 300 places available on a first-come-first-served basis
For issues with booking, email us
The disarray of the various social sciences is scandalous and deeply unscientific. This situation is fostered by the feudal nature of the academic disciplines, each of which encourages hostility to and isolation from the others. The future of social science, however, lies in strong trans-disciplinary research.
Professor Herbert Gintis
Professor Gintis offers a radical and path-breaking framework for unifying all the social sciences, and remarkably, in each of these social sciences, he has been a leading contributor. This is a fantastic opportunity to listen to one of the greatest living social scientists whose contribution is simply mind-boggling
Professor Sanjit Dhami of the Department of Economics

Do not miss this opportunity to hear from a principal figure within social science. Use the 'Book now' link in the event details table to book your place.

Publications include:

Herbert Gintis (2013) The Biology of Cultural Evolution, Quarterly Review of Biology 88: 117\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd120.

Samuel Bowles and Herbert Gintis (2011), A Cooperative Species: Human Reciprocity and its Evolution. Princeton University Press: Princeton.

Herbert Gintis (2009) The Bounds of Reason: Game Theory and the Unification of the Behavioural Sciences. Princeton University Press: Princeton.

Herbert Gintis (2003) The Hitchhiker\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Guide to Altruism: Genes-Culture Coevolution and the Internalization of Norms, Journal of Theoretical Biology 220: 407\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd418.

Herbert Gintis et al. (2001) Cooperation, Reciprocity and Punishment in Fifteen Small-scale Societies, American Economic Review 91: 73\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd78.

]]> No publisher jcm22 Lecture Economics Management College:SocSci Media Biology Sociology Media and Communications Psychology 2014-10-06T11:55:00Z Blog Entry University welcomes new President and Vice-Chancellor https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/september/university-welcomes-new-president-and-vice-chancellor Professor Paul Boyle gives video interview upon taking office Today (1 October), the University welcomes Professor Paul Boyle FBA, FRSE as our new President and Vice-Chancellor.

Professor Boyle succeeds Professor Sir Robert Burgess who has retired after 15 years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd distinguished service to the University.

Professor Paul Boyle was former Chief Executive of the Economic and Social Research Council and President of Science Europe.\ufffd\ufffd He was also International Champion of Research Councils UK with responsibility for international strategy on behalf of all seven Research Councils.

He is the ninth institutional head in the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds 90-year-plus history and its sixth Vice-Chancellor since the award of its Royal Charter in 1957.

In an interview for staff and students on our dedicated microsite, Professor Paul Boyle speaks of his delight at leading Leicester after serving as Chief Executive of the Economic and Social Research Council.
You can also find a biography, press release and welcome messages to staff and students (to be announced).

]]> No publisher sb661 Psychology Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Engineering Magazine:Research 2014-09-17T09:15:00Z Blog Entry Largest ever study of awareness during general anaesthesia https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/september/largest-ever-study-of-awareness-during-general-anaesthesia University of Leicester plays key role in new study that identifies risk factors and consequences for patients, including long-term psychological harm Accidental awareness during general anaesthesia (AAGA) occurs when general anaesthesia is intended but the patient remains conscious. It is one of the most feared complications of general anaesthesia for both patients and anaesthetists.

The largest ever study of awareness, the 5th National Audit Project (NAP5), which has been conducted over the last three years by the Royal College of Anaesthetists (RCoA) and the Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland (AAGBI) found a patient reporting rate of 1 per 19,000 operations. This incidence of spontaneous patient reports of awareness is much lower than estimates of awareness when patients are specifically asked about it after anaesthesia, which are as high as 1 in 600.

The researchers - including Professor Michael Wang (pictured) from the University's School of Psychology - studied 3 million general anaesthetics from every public hospital in UK and Ireland, and studied more than 300 new reports of awareness.

The extensive study showed that the majority of episodes of awareness are short-lived, occur before surgery starts or after it finishes, and do not always cause concern to patients.\ufffd\ufffd Despite this, 51% of episodes led to distress and 41% to longer-term psychological harm. Sensations experienced included tugging, stitching, pain, paralysis and choking. Patients described feelings of dissociation, panic, extreme fear, suffocation and even dying. Longer-term psychological harm often included features of post-traumatic stress disorder.

Professor Wang, Professor of Clinical Psychology at the University, is an author of the study. He said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdOur research has demonstrated the importance of understanding the range of long term reactions to AAGA and the need to be familiar with the characteristics of post-traumatic stress disorder following AAGA as well as its effects on quality of life.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe must understand the significance of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdawake paralysis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and how this can lead to longer-term psychological impacts. Many patients are left with persistent psychological problems which greatly impair quality of life. Commonly AAGA patients present with post traumatic stress disorder, other new anxiety states and/or clinical depression.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Psychology Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff 2014-09-09T23:05:18Z Blog Entry Researchers shed fresh light into how young and developing readers make sense of words https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/august/researchers-shed-fresh-light-into-how-young-and-developing-readers-make-sense-of-words Psychologists examine the importance of the position of letters in words for young readers

Skilled readers are often able to make sense of words suffering from \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtypos\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and jumbled up letter orders as long as the beginning and end letters of the words are correct.

But a new study suggests that young developing readers also have a similar understanding of how these outside letters can help make sense of words.

The study found that while developing young readers and skilled adult readers found it similarly difficult to correctly recognise anagrams that can form another word by switching the order of only the inside letters, both age groups found it equally easy to recognise anagrams when the outside letters also had to be switched around to form another word.

This is because the brain struggles to keep track of the position of inside letters when recognising words but assigns special importance to the outside letters.

The findings are important for understanding the role of letter position in children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds word recognition, including in dyslexia.

The research team consisted of Dr Kevin Paterson, PhD student Victoria McGowan, who recently obtained a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFuture Research Leaders\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Postdoctoral Fellowship, undergraduate student Josephine Read from the School of Psychology and Professor Tim Jordan from the Department of Psychology at Zayed University in Dubai.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Psychology Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research 2014-08-07T10:49:11Z Blog Entry How the Gaza conflict will traumatise a generation of young people https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/august/how-the-gaza-conflict-will-traumatise-a-generation-of-young-people Professor Panos Vostanis explores how adolescents are affected by psychological disorders in warzones A new study led by Professor Panos Vostanis (pictured) from the School of Psychology has examined adolescent victims of conflict in the Gaza strip and has found that exposure to war-torn environments has a lasting and damaging effect on their psychological wellbeing.

The paper, entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTrauma, PTSD, Anxiety and Coping Strategies among Palestinians Adolescents Exposed to War in Gaza\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd has been published in the Arab Journal of Psychiatry and investigates types of traumatic events experienced by Palestinian adolescents exposed to war in Gaza in relation to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety and coping strategies.

Of the adolescents studied, the majority witnessed mutilated bodies on TV, were exposed to heavy artillery shelling, saw evidence of shelling and heard sonic sounds from jetfighters, leaving a lasting impression on many.\ufffd\ufffd

Professor Vostanis said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe toll on the mental health of these young people tends to be exacerbated by poverty, which is endemic in Gaza. It's a double whammy for many of them. As well as the conflict itself, they are also affected by how their parents respond, by the provision of basic needs and if there's a sense of helplessness.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Psychology Magazine:Staff 2014-08-06T11:07:22Z Blog Entry
